title: Tuesday, 9th February, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE

Hi. Hello. Good morning. Welcome.

BE

It's Shrove Tuesday, meaning we get Frankfurt traders in fancy dress.

BE

11:03 am
BE

(Photos: Kai Pfaffenbach/Reuters)

BE

I guess that's a fair representation of how markets are right now.

BE

We're either Elton John sparkles or deep goth. There's not much inbetween.

11:04 am
BE

Having said that, today, we're mostly calm.

BE

FTSE flat-ish. 13 points to the better, 5703.

BE

Steadied at around a .... three year low, is it?

11:06 am
BE

Anyway, we can pin the steadiness on Deutsche Bank. I guess.

BE

But first, a bit of Fun with Bank CDS.

BE

11:06 am
BE

That's a big mashup of 5yr CDS for Deutsche, Barclays, UBS, CS, Commerzbank and SocGen.

BE

All back to around 2011 levels.

BE

Or if you just want just Deutsche ....

11:07 am
BE

BE

No problem, though. It can pay the AT1 coupons due 30 April.

BE

"capital and risk position remains strong," says CFO Marcus Schenck.

11:08 am
BE

Or as per the overnight press release it was panicked into .....

BE

E1bn of available distributable items to meet the E350m of coupons

BE

(down from E2.9bn of ADI in 2015. But ignore that detail. We're being positive today.)

11:09 am
BE

DB guidance based on 2016 unaudited German accounts ......

BE

......... the difficulty here being that no-one can understand German accounting. Though you'd hope Deutsche Bank would be better placed than most to give it a shot.

BE

As RBC says .......

11:09 am
BE

[DB] shares are trading at a significant discount on 0.37x latest reported TBV on the back of fears regarding capital which we see to be overdone - we forecast the CET1 ratio at 10.9% Q1 16 and 11.5% 2016e. The need for further litigation charges remains an uncertainty but DBK has EUR5.5bn of reserves and we have EUR2.5bn in our 2016 forecasts.

BE

The company had already stated that it expected to have sufficient capacity to pay the AT1 coupons at the results on 28 January but hadn't given the actual number. Given the 2015 stated loss driven by goodwill impairments and litigation charges there were significant concerns that it did not have adequate reserves (calculated under German accounting rules, which are very opaque) out of which to pay the coupons. The number of an ADI of EUR1bn for 2016 is pretty low and impacted by write-downs on subsidiaries and li ga on (net loss of EUR1.2bn offset by reserves of EUR1.1bn).

BE

As importantly, DBK estimates AT1 payment capacity for 2017 to start at EUR4.3bn, benefitting from the Hua Xia gain of EUR1.6bn expected at closing in H1 2016 as under German accounting it was held at book value and not written up as it was in IFRS. It also estimates another EUR1.9bn of reserves to be released. This is before any 2016 results so there could be some offset (we forecast a net loss of EUR1.3bn under IFRS) but this screens as a sizeable buffer.

11:10 am
BE

The release does not mention the Maximum Distributable Amount (MDA) which is the other limit on coupon payments. This is because it is not an issue for 2016 given a 177bp buffer between the 10.75% SREP CET1 ratio requirement and 1 January 2016 reported CET1 under phase in of 12.52%. For 2017 we would also expect MDA to be sufficient relative to an 11.25% estimated SREP requirement.

BE

In terms of the sector ...........

BE

Good note out from Jonathan Pierce at Exane this morning.

11:12 am
BE

Going through the UK lenders, "Stressed but not distressed" being the conclusion.

BE

The gist being that the widening in bank wholesale funding spreads is not 2008 levels but still worth keeping an eye on.

BE

Senior debt has widened 50bps and subordinated debt over 100bps since the start of the year. AT1 spreads are over 200bps higher. Premiums for Hold Co debt are also rising - important for a sector that needs to re-position over GBP200bn in the coming years. These moves have clear implications for margin. A further risk is that prolonged stress feeds through to higher deposit costs, exacerbating the impact. This would be amplified if swap rates remain at current levels through more severe structural hedge re-pricing, with the 5yr UK swap 200bps below where it was in 2011.

11:14 am
BE

Actually, first par first.

BE

UK bank share prices are down 18% since the start of the year. A degree of stress is now priced in but on a capital adjusted 9 times 2017E EPS, the sector's valuation is hardly distressed. And there is plenty to worry about. This research discusses the various feedback loops from market dislocation into the banks and considers the consequences for the sector should this dislocation become prolonged. Our analysis suggests the eventual impact on profits and capital could be material. While not our central scenario this helps make sense of recent share price movements.

BE

Now the third par. Impairments.

11:15 am
BE

Investment grade and high yield spreads have widened across many industries, not just the
obvious ones. We do not expect a substantial increase in impairment charges for the sector but the combination of deterioration in gross charges compounded by a faster decline in releases and recoveries is plausible. This would be compounded by higher RWA through pro-cyclicality.

BE

And finally ......

BE

We are not concerned about the banks’ capital or liquidity positions, that are immeasurability better than they were, but the above risks are almost certainly driving the sector’s cost of capital higher. We increase COE by 1 percentage point, less than the move in AT1 yields, driving target prices lower for all banks. In summary, we do not dismiss the recent share price performance as illogical and remain cautious on the sector.

11:15 am
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 161.75, down 2.15 (-1.31%), High: 165.70, Low: 159.70, Volume: 17.38m
HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 439.10, up 0.65 (+0.15%), High: 445.40, Low: 433.80, Volume: 14.60m
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 59.40, up 0.0445 (+0.07%), High: 60.13, Low: 58.82, Volume: 61.54m
11:15 am
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 230.10, down 0.6 (-0.26%), High: 234.60, Low: 226.70, Volume: 4.63m
Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 426.10, down 0.9 (-0.21%), High: 430.70, Low: 417.85, Volume: 2.49m
BE

Global bank index down 16% YTD, incidentally.

11:16 am
BE

Barclays down 25%.

BE

Anyway, before we move on, here's Goldman on DB.

BE

We see four main factors driving the recent share price move: (1) concern
surrounding the non-payment of AT1 coupon; (2) sharp moves in the CDS
market, which consequently lead (3) market participants to question the
banks’ funding position, and (4) year-to-date P&L trend concerns.
Today’s announcement should alleviate AT1 related fears, in particular as
the bank included its 2017 payment capacity disclosure (€4.3 bn). On the
issue of the CDS move, we note that the “liquidity” of this instrument
leaves a question mark over its message. To this end, were DBK to
demonstrate its ability to issue a long-dated, unsecured benchmark, on
market terms, the CDS moves (and the overall funding debate) would be
put in a relevant context, in our view.
The final point, on P&L trends, will remain a concern in a challenging year
that 2016 is shaping up to be. Indeed, the structural weaknesses of the
business model (which we discussed in detail in: When an 8% ROE is just
an aspiration; Neutral, September 15, 2015) leave DBK disproportionately
exposed to market speculation in periods of stress, in our view.

11:17 am
BE

DBK has improved its capital position on CET1 basis (4Q415: 11.1%),
however, leverage remains tight (3.5%). Challenging operating conditions,
regulatory and litigation uncertainty will continue to expose the shares to
higher levels of volatility, in our opinion.

undefined
BE

That's enough banks though. What else?

11:19 am
BE

(@northlondon: Pru holding RNS isn't showing up on my system. Do you have a link?)

BE

Sophos, then.

Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 188.30, down 17.9 (-8.68%), High: 212.00, Low: 184.10, Volume: 1.06m
11:20 am
BE

Down 8% on in-line results and reaffirmed guidance.

BE

The problem -- as we've said repeatedly -- is that Sophos numbers are really difficult to add up.

BE

So when something looks a bit problematic -- such as, today, we have cash EBITDA margins weakening -- it's difficult to see in isolation.

11:23 am
BE

There's a very easy bear case to make for Sophos and I'm slightly surprised it hasn't been targeted in that way yet.

BE

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE

Billings growth remains strong - even as base gets tougher: Sophos
reported 17.4% l-f-l billings growth in 3Q16. This was ahead of the 13%
growth we forecast for 2H16 and, while there is no clear 3Q16 consensus, we
think this is also above investor expectations. The growth is a slowdown from
the 24% l-f-l billings growth reported in 1H16 - but this reflects the tougher
basis of comparison in 2H (13% growth in 1H15, 21% in 2H15) and so we
believe this represents a strong performance. Revenues were $121.4m,
+11.9% l-f-l.

11:23 am
BE

APJ & Network lead the way: By region, APJ was the star (+48.1% l-f-l
billings) with Sophos highlighting deals in Japan (these pushed out the
average deal length – but only slightly to 28.5 months from 28 months). The
APJ performance was even an acceleration from the +37% seen in 1H. The
impact of the tougher base was seen more in the Americas (+16% after +26%
in 1H) and EMEA (+10.9% after +19% in 1H). By product, it is no surprise to
see the Network business continuing to lead the growth. Network billings
grew 31.6% l-f-l - only slightly down from 34% in 1H. Enduser billings were
+8%, after +14.5% in 1H. Other product billings were down 13.5% - however
this is due to the fact that the base period saw a large one-off sale in this
business line and we believe other product billings would have been up ex this
impact.

BE

Cash EBITDA margins down YTD, but as expected as base eases
materially in 4Q16: Sophos reported cash EBITDA of $34.8m, a margin of
24.6%, down 120bps y/y. YTD cash EBITDA margins have fallen 90bps. We
would highlight that Sophos had an unusual sales & marketing phasing
pattern in 2015 as the company embarked on a significant marketing
campaign in 4Q15. This meant that in 2015 S&M spend was heavily weighted
to 4Q, while it has been more evenly spread in 2016. This depressed the 4Q15
margins - and slightly depresses the first 9 month margins of 2016 - as we
have seen. Sophos now has an easy base of comparison in 4Q16 (4Q15
margins were down 580bps sequentially when 4Q should be a strong quarter),
which reassures us the margin improvement required to hit Sophos' guidance
(a FY margin of 21.4% in 4Q16 requires +260bps 4Q15) is achievable.

BE

FY guidance reiterated: Sophos raised its guidance at the 1H16 stage and
now reiterates that guidance at the 3Q16 stage. The company expects FY16 l-f-
l billings to be up in a range of "mid teens to 20%". Sophos also expects FY16
cash EBITDA margins to be "in excess of the 21.3% achieved in the prior
period".

11:25 am
BE

And Peel Hunt.

BE

Investment Case: Sophos is the only cybersecurity company solely focused on
mid-market network and endpoint IT security, a $9.6bn market. Sophos has
strong recurring billings (81%) and revenue, a globally diverse customer base and
a strong cash EBITDA margin (23%+), FCF Yield (8%+) and dividend of 20%
of FCF. It is growing at c19% pa, (nearly three times market growth), with an
experienced management team that understands the importance of innovation.

BE

Catalysts: Following today’s report, we continue to believe that the mid-term
drivers of the shares are international market share growth, (in Asia Pacific &
Japan and North America), and an innovation-led, significant cross-sell and upsell
opportunity, (Security Heartbeat and Sophos’ cloud platform). Long-term
Sophos will benefit from the key cybersecurity trends that we outlined in our
sector note last year “Come On In”. These are: 1) increasing enterprise budgets;
2) best-practice evolution to detection and response; 3) consolidation of the
vendor landscape towards more intelligent integrated solutions; and 4) businesses
increasing outsourcing of IT security to Managed Service Providers.

11:26 am
BE

Valuation: Our price target of 360p is based on our DCF valuaiton. We shall
review our financial forecasts after the Sophos conference call this morning,
however we expect consensus estimates to remain broadly unchanged.

BE

(@alewis2005: think that was back in November. It had competition clearance somewhere in Asia overnight.)

BE

(@alewis2005: South Korea, in fact.)

11:27 am
undefined
BE

DPL? Certainly.

Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 3,083, down 46 (-1.47%), High: 3,170, Low: 3,014, Volume: 735.94k
11:28 am
BE

Hit very hard yesterday, continuing lower today. Not helped by this .....

BE

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3zZHoM25P

BE

Hedge fund managers are taking short positions against the biggest listed provider of luxury London homes in a bet that weakening emerging markets will put the once buoyant sector into reverse.
A small group of funds are targeting the shares of Berkeley Group, the main listed proxy for new high-end London property, amid signs that Asian and Russian buyers are deserting the market.

11:29 am
BE

Odey Asset Management, BlueMountain Capital Management and Anchorage Capital took short positions against the FTSE 100 builder in January, worth 2.2 per cent of its share capital, according to data disclosed to the Financial Conduct Authority.
The short positions run against analysts’ consensus that Berkeley is well positioned to continue growing — and indicate the hedge funds believe pricing and transaction levels for luxury London homes have further to fall.

BE

Skip to the comment box for lots of people arguing about the low quality of developments near their houses.

BE

The interesting idea in the story, for me at least, was about the FX risk of selling off plan, offshore

11:31 am
BE

As in, you buy your two-bedroom off plan in some sweaty hotel suite and put down a 10% deposit.

BE

The extraction currency you paid with then falls xx per cent against sterling and the remaining 90 per cent of your unbuilt flat is suddenly a lot more expensive.

BE

To Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with the whatever.

11:33 am
BE

Anyway, Anthony Codling at Jefferies has a long walk through the argument.

BE

Perhaps the box office hit 'The 'Big Short' is spurring investors to short Berkeley
group in what some perceive as an overheated London housing market. We
would not short Berkeley Group as its investment case is based on strong
foundations, solid ground and physical properties rather than intangible
synthetic mortgage products. We still believe cash is king and Berkeley will
meet its promises to return cash to shareholders; go long not short.

BE

Press reports that several investors are shorting Berkeley Group It appears to us
that some investors are worried about over heating in certain 'high end' pockets of the
London housing market and are using Berkeley as a proxy to bet against this market.
In our view Berkeley is the wrong vehicle Much like in 'The Big Short' those initially
wanting to bet against the US housing market did not have a vehicle to go short against, so
they had to create one, however we do not believe that Berkeley Group is the appropriate
vehicle. With ASPs of £550,000 this year and £650,000 next Berkeley hardly, in our view,
provides a playground in which the rich and famous play at property developing and
speculating. Mention trophy assets to Mr Pidgley and he is likely to explain in words that
will leave no room for ambiguity that he does not invest in trophy assets. Mr Pidgley also
has, in our view, a rather enviable track record in calling the London housing market.

11:34 am
BE

Help to Buy London Interestingly the evening papers yesterday (Evening Standard - West
End Final) ran with the headline 'Renters rush for Help to Buy Loans', suggesting that 15,000
first time buyers have applied for the new scheme in the first 7 days since its launch. Equity
investors will of course be aware that Berkeley is the natural beneficiary here.
We have a shortage of homes across London, over the last 20 years production has
averaged less than 20,000 homes a year, compared to household population growth of
50,000 pa. Over the next 10 years the population in London is expected to grow by 1 million
and yet to the total planning pipeline for new homes (even if there was sufficient labour to
build these homes) is around 240,000.

BE

Help to Rent London The capital is crying our for rental properties and if Berkeley's
overseas investor demand were to wane we know of around 20 funds raising but struggling
to invest money in the fast growing private rented market.
The £175m question Let us not forget that Mr Perrins and Mr Pidgley are seeking at their
upcoming EGM to adjust their LTIP, to limit their payout to £175m each should they return
the £16.34p per share to investors. If the London market does slow, we are sure they reduce
or stop buying land, so cash generation remains strong and dividends are very likely, in our
view, to get paid. With a yield of 6.4% we see attractions at these levels.
Leave (most of) the rest of the sector out of this Quite how concerns over high end
London should impact the national and 'non-London' regional listed housebuilders escapes
us. We are not aware of any 'perceived' bubbles outside of London and the South East
we doubt their (Help to Buy aided) returns are under threat. However one listed London
housebuilder (Telford Homes TEF LN, N/R) seems to have been neglected by the shorting
parties, shouldn't they short that London housebuilder as well?
Valuation: At 3129p Berkeley trades on a CY2016 P/B of 2.15x and offers a yield of 6.4%.
Our 4650p PT is based on the simple average of a P/B multiple of 1.75x and a PER of 14x
applied to our CY2016 estimates plus dividend probability weighted across our Neutral Case
(50%), Upside Case (45%) and Downside Case (5%). Risks: Berkeley's fortunes are linked
to the underlying UK housing market significant reductions in UK house prices, mortgage
availability or material changes to the supply chain may lead us to reduce our estimates.

BE

Sorry for the formatting.

11:35 am
undefined
BE

The great Anglo issue raised by @gregamoils: who'd buy this thing?

BE

There has been speculation around Anglo, but to be clear the takeover side of things looks very low quality.

11:36 am
BE

As in ... it's up 30% or so since the start of the year .... it must be a bid target. Easy story for a certain type of trader.

BE

However .........

BE

Other punters have been slightly more useful with their speculation.

11:37 am
BE

One theory -- which I think turned up in a local paper first -- was that Anglo might scale up its disposal plan to exit Brazil entirely.

BE

As in, walk away from Minas Rio and the other one, assuming they could find buyers.

BE

Another idea around on Friday was that it could get together with South 32.

11:39 am
BE

Market caps don't work for a merger so, perhaps, some kind of all-share stealth rights issue type deal.

BE

Now, we've been discouraged from taking this too seriously.

BE

S32's reportedly in talks to buy Anglo's phosphates mine, and is also majority partner in a South African chrome JV

11:41 am
BE

It's understandable that they'd talk. But Cutifani's generally considered too cautious to do anything Glencore-level dramatic.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 350.45, down 25.65 (-6.82%), High: 373.25, Low: 347.95, Volume: 5.68m
BE

Here's that Citi note referred to on the right.

11:42 am
BE

Our analysis of the company’s asset portfolio against commodity price volatility (past 6 years) suggests a probability of the company’s NPV being less than zero of around 27%. In this case, we assume Anglo would have to conduct an emergency rights issue to secure the value of the equity. Given we think the balance of probability is that this does not happen, we retain a positive target price of £2.00. We maintain our SELL/High Risk rating.

BE

We believe that Anglo clearly requires some help from a recovery in depressed commodity prices. This would raise the value that the market is ascribing to its operating assets and enable it to start generating some free cash flow again. At spot, executing on an Anglo self-help story looks severely challenging. At these levels, we argue that a decision to sell assets or its own shares would not be a value-creation tactic – rather a survival tactic.

BE

This is the highest-risk alternative but offers shareholders the highest potential rewards, if the strategy pays off. A further 31.6% reduction in Anglo’s EV from here would imply zero value for its shares. A 10% hike in EV would raise its market-implied equity value by 32%. This gearing is near an all-time high.

11:42 am
BE

The challenge for Anglo under this scenario is that its net debt is worth 68% of the total value that the equity market is ascribing to its operating assets. This is an all-time high, by some distance. In other words, Anglo would have to sell 68% of its operating asset base at current market values to remove all of its group net debt.

BE

If Anglo were to conduct a large rights issue to retire all of its net debt, we gauge that this would lower the probability of its NPV being less than zero from 27% to 16%. This is due to the removal of all net debt. Effectively what this states is that there is a 16% chance of Anglo’s operating assets (EV) being worth less than zero in the long term. The challenge with a rights issue is that Anglo would have to increase its shares in issue by 217% (at today’s share price) if it chose to pay down all of its group net debt.

BE

Some people also pinning Anglo's fall on Kumba results this morning, but they were in line.

11:44 am
undefined
BE

Otherwise on the miners, here's RBC saying sell everything pretty much.

BE

Fundamentals remain very challenging in the mining sector. Commodity oversupply is not improving fast enough and long-term demand conditions are deteriorating. Our analysis suggests there will still be some time before the erosion in cash flow and balance sheet strength stop; a heightened concern for the diversified miners as debt levels are already at record levels vs EV. We acknowledge that sentiment is very poor, but we do not expect a fundamental turnaround in the near-term and this could have material implications on equity value.

11:45 am
BE

Rio sell. BHP neutral.

BE

Glencore buy!

BE

Key to our thesis for the diversified miners is maintaining sufficient financial flexibility to provide shareholders with a path through to subsequent cycles. We expect that BHP Billiton will cut its dividend sharply (by 75%) to maintain flexibility and stave off further credit rating downgrades. This, and Rio Tinto's concentration of profitability in structurally-challenged iron ore, will likely see Rio's relative flexibility erode the most over the coming 12 months, in the absence of a price rally. Over the medium term, we are more constructive on potential oil market recovery (favouring BHP), although this too will likely result in increased capex. All of this follows a sharp period of outperformance by Rio. We have also upgraded Glencore today to Outperform (135p target price) from Sector Perform as we see its aggressive actions to restore financial flexibility reverting some of the relative compression that the equity endured in 2015.

11:46 am
BE

We argue that fundamental valuations, especially for long-life assets that require supportive (higher) prices to justify re-investment, leave little validity in NAV estimates. Until the bottom is found, increasing financial burden from rising ND/EBITDA levels will likely keep the market focused on near-term cash generation - meaning we believe spot prices are most useful. Any further reduction of cash flow is likely to see accelerating compression in the equity. We set our 12-month target prices for RIO and BHP based on a 90%/10% blend of EV/EBITDA multiples and 1.0x NAV in reflection of this feature.

BE

Commodity markets are cyclical, and as such prices will rise again, especially where supply is tighter, however, the risk is around timing. The near term is likely to be a painful exploration of corporate discomfort. We accept that short, sharp rallies are likely to occur on a frequent basis and that tactical positioning will be necessary for sector investment. Medium-term, the debt in the sector is likely to create significant dislocation; opportunities are likely to arise for those with the most financial flexibility.

BE

With the uncertainty around valuation, we believe macro stability, greater visibility in Chinese demand, acceptance by corporates that current debt and dividend structures are unsustainable and (eventual) supply reductions will be the best indicators of an appropriate time to become more constructive on the sector .

11:47 am
BE

107 pages of that. If you're interested, speak to RBC.

undefined
BE

Fantasy M&A, maybe?

11:49 am
BE

ABN Amro seems to have read that revival of the Hays theory from a few weeks ago and thought, "why not?"

BE

As in, this theory: http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3zZHoM25P

BE

Which, as we tried to stress in the report, was a pretty poor quality rumour. But sometimes they come true.

11:50 am
BE

Konrad Zomer of ABN thinks it might, certainly.

BE

After a year of share price weakness, there is once again press speculation about
Hays becoming a take-over target. In this report, we evaluate the financial and
strategic implications of Randstad or Adecco buying Hays. Both could
comfortably finance it (even at a 30% bid premium), and we conclude that
Randstad needs such a deal more than Adecco. We believe it is worth the risk.

BE

We have worked out a case of a 30% bid premium (valuing Hays at GBP
2.2bn), and a target leverage ratio of 2.0x for Randstad and Adecco, both
comfortably within covenants. We find that such a deal would be 9% earnings
accretive for Randstad in its first year, and 4% for Adecco. Randstad could finance
such a deal without issuing new shares, on our calculations.

11:51 am
BE

By acquiring Hays, Randstad would lift its exposure in perm placement and
professional staffing to 18% of gross profit and 35% of group revenues, respectively.
For Adecco, this would be 17%/39%. Furthermore, Hays has built an impressive
franchise in Germany, and has successfully turned its UK business around, both of
which would add substantial strategic value to both Adecco and Randstad.

BE

Neither Randstad nor Adecco target transformational deals. However, Hays’ share
price has underperformed significantly, which provides a tangible opportunity. We
believe Randstad is currently better equipped to pull off this deal than Adecco, and
we believe it would be worth the risk. We reiterate our Buy recommendation on
Hays, and set a TP of 170p/share, from 175p.

BE

Which is pretty straightforward, as arguments go. To be clear, though, we have no info.

11:52 am
Hays PLC (HAS:LSE): Last: 115.60, down 0.6 (-0.52%), High: 117.30, Low: 114.90, Volume: 1.28m
undefined
BE

And of course, there's Cambian.

11:53 am
BE

Have a read of this.

BE

http://seekingalph...valued-real-estate

BE

A long piece on Seeking Alpha from last week on the value in Cambian's property portfolio.

11:55 am
BE

Which seems to skip over the detail that the property portfolio is made of properties.

BE

Special schools, hospitals, day care facilities. That kind of thing.

BE

One could argue that, if Cambian were to be liquidated and all those special schools, hospitals, day care facilities were passed on to Berkeley Group to turn into luxury flats, you'd be quids in.

11:57 am
BE

But there may also be a quite severe effect on civilised society, which I'd suspect would have counterbalancing effect on house prices.

BE

Anyway. Onto today's profit warning.

BE

Investec can summarise.

11:58 am
BE

Today’s trading statement indicates FY15 EBITDA of c.£46m, below the ‘not less than £49m’ guidance given at the last update on 22 October. Whilst occupancy has increased by 260, with revenues and wages rising in-line with expectations, the company seems unable to forecast or manage its costs. We place our forecasts, recommendation and TP under review until further detail is available following a conference call at 8.30am, but anticipate EBITDA downgrades of c.6% for FY15E and c.20% for FY16E.

BE

(@fjp73: we make the same argument with supermarkets all the time. Welcome back, by the way.)

BE

Revenues progressing, but weakness in cost management. Indicated FY15 revenues of c.£292m are above our £286m estimate, reflecting the increases in occupancy. However Cambian has identified ‘weaknesses in its cost management process’ which meant it took longer to manage down other (non-wage-related) costs. PwC has been appointed to review the supplier management systems, central HR has been restructured and recruitment/training processes have been redesigned.
EBITDA downgrades of c.6% in FY15E. The company now expects FY15 EBITDA of £46m, 6% below October 22nd guidance (not less than £49m). Minimal guidance has been provided for FY16, but Cambian anticipates modest growth in EBITDA. We had been forecasting £64m, implying downgrades of at least 20% (if we interpret modest growth as 5%). No final dividend will be paid for FY15.
Net debt in-line with estimates for FY15. Perhaps the only positive sentiment in the statement is that net debt of £242m was in-line with our estimates and within banking covenants for end Dec 2015. The company anticipates only £20m of CapEx in FY16 (vs £46m in FY15 and our £43m estimate) and has entered discussions with its banks to agree revised future covenants.
Forecasts/TP/Recommendation placed under review. This statement is disappointing, particularly coming so soon after the last profit warning and will further dent investor confidence. Whilst we believe the underlying market remains strong, we are concerned about management’s lack of visibility into future costs. We are also concerned that guidance may slip further once the new CFO is appointed and further detail on the outlook for FY16 is available.

11:59 am
BE

And Barclays.

BE

Cambian’s trading update this morning guides for 2015 revenue of £292m vs. our estimate of £290m and adjusted EBITDA to be not less than £46m vs. our expectations of £49m. This represents a 6% miss on EBITDA and drops through to a 12% miss on adjusted EPS. The cause of the past two misses has been weakness on the cost side due to ambitious capital expansion plans that did not ultimately deliver. Further CMBN has guided to deliver ‘modest growth’ in adjusted EBITDA for 2016 vs. our estimate of £62m. Guidance on capex is £46m for 2015 vs. our estimate of £55m with a step down to £20m in 2016, in line with our expectations. Net debt was £241m at FY2015, representing 4.92x Net Debt/EBITDA, against a current covenant of 4.95x. In light of the downgrade the Board will not be recommending the payment of a final dividend for 2015 vs. our estimate of 0.36p/share. The company has an interim CFO in place and is entering into discussions with its lending banks to agree revised future debt covenants.

Summary. While the company points to a satisfactory start to 2016,
investors are likely to disagree. We believe there is likely to be value in
the business (particularly the real estate), however it is likely to take
longer than expected to realize and investors are likely to question
whether management can deliver. We believe a third party could see
value in the asset base, but frankly is probably best to wait on the
outcome of the bank negotiations.

Applying these multiples to Cambian indicates significant
upside even on 2015 earnings that are arguably trough. Applying these
multiples to our 2015 Cambian forecasts implies £2.79 and £1.80 per
share respectively. If we assume the company is able to deliver the
recovery we are forecasting in 2016, then applying these multiples to
FY16 forecasts implies £3.38 and £2.73 per share respectively. We
believe this analysis underpins our share price target which represents
120% potential upside to last night's close.
